awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Modeling for the Enhancement of Learning Chemistry (ModEL-C): Measuring cognitive load & impact of modeling activities across the chemistry curriculum
awd_abstract_narration:
The ModEL-C project will examine how cognitive load affects students' conceptual learning through the use of chemistry and biochemistry models.  The disciplines of chemistry and biochemistry present a particular challenge to students with abstract concepts that can lead to rampant and resistant misconceptions, affecting both learning and student retention.  Based on the data collected from this study, the project team will implement three-dimensional (3D) virtual and physical modeling activities across the chemistry and biochemistry curriculum that optimize cognitive load and thereby enhance student learning.   Ultimately this work will create better consumers of chemistry and biochemistry education. 

This project will characterize the cognitive load of 3D physical and virtual modeling activities by defining what and how many cognitive tasks and concepts are accessed while using those 3D modeling activities in general, organic and biochemistry courses. To this end, a student cohort and select content experts will participate in a simulated learning environment, completing modeling activities while their cognition is monitored by means of eye-tracking and electroencephalogram (EEG) technologies.  Moving forward, this project will provide evidence to more intelligently design and execute 3D virtual and physical modeling activities to decrease their cognitive load en route to deepening students' ability to understand biomolecular interactions and overcome misconceptions.  This evidence will create avenues for curricular change, from minimal to drastic, for those researchers and practitioners interested in conceptual changes as well as the advancement of the NGSS practice of modeling.

por.por_cntn:
Little is known on how to best design, implement and assess 3D physical and virtual modeling activities that target student misconceptions and learning difficulties. This is particularly true for chemistry and biochemistry disciplines. Here these courses rely heavily on visual literacy and modeling to convey abstract phenomena to students. This project is a collaborative proposal between the chemistry and biochemistry faculty at University of Minnesota, Rochester (UMR) and visualization and human cognition researchers at Kennesaw State University (KSU). The goal of this project is to increase (bio)chemistry students' conceptual understanding of structure function relationships by decreasing the extrinsic cognitive load of targeted 3D virtual and physical modeling activities embedded across the chemistry and biochemistry curricula. This proposal aimed to characterize the cognitive complexity of the 3D physical and virtual modeling activities by defining what and how many cognitive tasks and concepts are accessed using the 3D modeling activities in general, organic and biochemistry courses. Specifically, the central hypothesis was that by providing 3D modeling activities focused on the structure-function concepts throughout general and organic chemistry, when faced with 3D modeling of macromolecules in biochemistry, students will not find the tasks as cognitively demanding. 

 

To this end, we created an iterative design process for these modeling activities that relied on biometric data collected in simulated learning environments.  These biometric data were recorded using electroencephalographic (EEG) and eye-tracking tools and voice recordings. In addition, observational and rubric analyses of student responses to activities from mock classrooms and real classroom sessions provided further data for the iterative classroom activity design process. In all 7 activities, 5 novel and 2 previously designed, that incorporated 3D physical or 3D virtual models were developed and tested in the learning environments. The results of our study spend the most time on the first question, regardless of the activity or course. The re-scaffolding of questions in the activity redesign process did help students think more like experts on the activities. Additionally, students struggle the most with structure-functional relationship questions. Many ignoring the model all together to answer these questions. This indicates a need for models to be used frequently, with instructor demonstrates and through active learning, so students can learn and become comfortable with using models to answer questions.

 

In all, this project provides a new method for assessing students' use of 3D physical and virtual models. This project also developed an iterative design and assessment strategy for instructors, which is crucial to developing and refining course materials that best serve student concept and skill growth in chemistry and biochemistry. Many of the products of this project are tools (3D physical and virtual models along with active learning materials) for instructors to use and refine for use in these and related courses. As such this project impacts both teaching and educational experiences. Instructors can use these interventions in their courses, which are designed to especially help underrepresented students succeed in STEM courses. Instructors can learn from our design process to approach making new assessments and curricula that incorporate 3D virtual and physical models. Students benefit from better, targeted design of these curricula and supporting materials. 

 

Intellectual Merit

This proposal advances the knowledge and understanding of (bio)chemistry for education researchers and practitioners by identifying how and when students learn using 3D models as it relates to identified misconceptions within the cross-cutting structure-function concept. Not only is this knowledge currently absent in the chemical and biochemical education curriculum, but also the techniques for measuring the described phenomena are novel and as a generality research on science and engineering practices at the undergraduate level are largely understudied. 

 

Broader Impacts

The results of this project are likely to make an impact by producing better consumers of (bio)chemistry education. The project proposes improvements to chemistry and biochemistry education and educator development at the undergraduate level. This project offers an avenue for curricular change for those researchers and practitioners interested in not only conceptual changes but also the advancement of the NGSS practice of modeling. As chemistry and biochemistry curricula are pursued by students planning to enter into the STEM workforce, this project?s underlying ambition is to increase STEM retention in particularly challenging coursework. This work also supports a central aim in science education, as stated by Gilbert and Boutler (1998), wherein ?learners are supported by constructing more accurate and adequate mental models of scientific models through teaching models.? This approach of the use of models and modeling has the potential to increase science education and broaden its inclusivity, a long term goal in the National Research Council?s report on discipline-based education research (2012).
